I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program  is  a  unique 
alliance  of  eight  countries  supported  by  six  multilateral  institutions1 working  to  achieve 
development  through  cooperation,  leading  to  accelerated  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is the program secretariat. At the core of the 
Program is an overall institutional framework (OIF) that comprises (i) an annual ministerial 
conference that makes policy and strategic decisions and provides guidance in all areas of the 
Program; (ii) senior officials' meetings (SOM) that coordinate cross-sectoral issues and prepare 
for  ministerial  conferences;  (iii)  sector  coordinating  committees  for  transport,  energy,  trade 
facilitation,  and  trade  policy  that  coordinate  sectorwide  issues,  strategy  articulation,  and 
program  development  and  implementation;  and  (iv)  a  national  focal  point  (NFP)  in  each 
participating country, that ensures effective coordination among government agencies and other 
parties concerned. The OIF drives the CAREC Program's collaborative approach to the design 
and implementation of concrete development initiatives, the benefits of which stretch beyond 
national frontiers. The importance of continued support to the OIF has been highlighted in a 
number of technical assistance completion reports.2  
 
2.  At  CAREC’s  fifth  ministerial  conference  in  October  2006,  ministers  adopted  the 
comprehensive action plan (CAP),3 underscoring their countries' strong commitment to pursuing 
regional cooperation. The CAP is being implemented through the OIF and will guide the work of 
the Program over the medium term. Ministers expressed appreciation for ADB's contribution as 
program  secretariat  and  requested  continued  strong  support  for  the  CAREC  Program  to 
accelerate the momentum of cooperation and to ensure efficient and effective implementation of 
the CAP.4 In response to this request, and given ADB's strong commitment to the CAREC 
Program and to regional cooperation and integration,5 this regional technical assistance (RETA) 
will support the smooth and proactive functioning of the CAREC OIF in 2007–2009. The RETA 
design and monitoring framework is shown in Appendix 1.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The case for regional economic cooperation among CAREC countries is clear. The 
geographical,  economic,  and  historical  context,  as  well  as  the  asymmetrical  distribution  of 
natural resources in the region, makes CAREC countries uniquely interdependent and points to 
the substantial benefits of improved regional cooperation.7 Economic development and poverty 
reduction are best supported through rapid, sustained, pro-poor, and inclusive growth. Fostering 
such  growth  in  CAREC  countries  will  require  efficient  regional  transport  infrastructure, 
rehabilitation of energy networks, and seamless transit of goods across the region to external 
markets. Further progress in each of these areas is contingent on regional cooperation.

4.  In  line  with  ADB's  1994  policy  on  regional  cooperation,8 the  CAREC  Program  has 
followed a phased approach, moving from economic analysis and institutional assessments to 
identification and prefeasibility analysis of investment projects, and on to expanded support for 
policy dialogue and institutional reform. The Program's focus on improving infrastructure and 
policy and institutional environments in the priority areas of transport, energy, and trade to (i) 
lessen the region's geographic disadvantages, (ii) promote intra- and interregional trade and 
transit,  and  (iii)  enhance  sustainable  use  of  natural  resources,  is  well-aligned  with  ADB's 
Medium-Term Strategy II9 and Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy.10  
 
5.  From the establishment of the CAREC Unit in 2000 to the end of April 2007, ADB 
approved 16 loans totaling $500 million for 12 regional investment projects related to CAREC's 
priority sectors. Cofinancing of $134 million was mobilized for seven of these projects.11  
 
6.  This support has included RETAs for the development and operation of CAREC's OIF. 
Major lessons learned from these RETAs include that (i) regional cooperation is a long-term 
process requiring sustained political will and mutual trust; (ii) a lack of understanding of the 
benefits of regional cooperation, and the costs of noncooperation, constitute an obstacle to 
deepening regional cooperation; (iii) institutional and capacity development is required to enable 
cooperation; and (iv) tangible results are needed to further advance regional cooperation.12  
 
7.  These lessons inform the CAP, which represents the beginning of a new phase of the 
CAREC Program. The CAP will ensure that investments in the priority areas of transport, trade, 
and energy13 are coordinated and that CAREC serves as a proactive facilitator of practical 
regional projects and policy initiatives. The CAP also provides for broadening the Program on a 
project-specific  basis  in  new  second-tier  areas  (human  resource  development,  agriculture, 
environment, disaster management and preparedness, and tourism).  
 
8.  The  ongoing  development  of  sector  strategies  in  transport,  energy,  and  trade14 is 
expected to result in a significantly expanded program of regional projects and policy actions. 
Each strategy will provide (i) a clear long-term vision expressing the shared objectives of 
participating countries, (ii) measurable actions in the short term (1–2 years) and medium term 
(3–5 years), and (iii) policy measures and priority investments required to achieve the actions.15 
  
9.  Smooth functioning of the OIF will be critical to maintaining the Program's momentum, 
supporting the adoption of the sector strategies, and effectively implementing both the strategies 
and the expanded work program contained in the CAP. A number of important challenges lie 
before the CAREC Program.

(i)  Strengthening  project  orientation  to  ensure  OIF  activities  result  in  effective 
projects. CAREC will contribute by providing an environment for frank project-
oriented discussion at the committee, senior official, and ministerial level. 
(ii)  Institutionalizing a regional perspective in project and policy dialogue to ensure 
decisions promote region-wide development. CAREC will contribute by fulfilling 
the commitment in the CAP to bring regional perspectives into development 
planning of participating countries and multilateral institutions. 
(iii)  Strengthening the strategic clarity of the Program. This will be achieved through 
the sector strategies and through establishing the CAREC Institute16 to undertake 
research, training, and dialogue activities to support opportunity analysis and 
informed decision making (para. 16).  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the RETA will be accelerated economic growth and poverty reduction in 
the CAREC countries. Through support for the OIF and CAREC Institute, the RETA will enable 
the CAREC Program to implement the CAP and the sector strategies (transport, energy, and 
trade)  which  are  being  prepared,  and  strengthen  the  collaborative  approach  to  concept-
development, design, and implementation of concrete projects and policy actions to improve 
transport connectivity, facilitate rational management and use of energy and natural resources, 
and enable increased trade among CAREC participating countries and with external markets. 
These actions will contribute to economic growth and improved living standards in CAREC 
countries. The RETA will also support analytical work and capacity development to enable the 
OIF to make informed decisions on strategic questions facing the Program and guide the 
broadening and deepening of the Program into a second tier of activities on a project basis. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Drawing on lessons learned from completed CAREC RETAs, appropriate flexibility will 
be applied in implementation to accommodate the evolving nature of the Program and to ensure 
the secretariat is able to effectively respond to the directions set by the annual ministerial 
conference. The conference outcomes will shape an annual CAREC work program to ensure 
the practical, project-based focus of the Program is maintained. The RETA will strengthen the 
OIF, and thereby the CAREC Program, through outputs in the following three areas.  
 
1.  Strengthening Regional Cooperation 
12.  The RETA will further develop and maintain an environment for open and frank dialogue 
on regional cooperation issues as a means to deepen mutual trust and understanding among 
participating countries. The RETA will fund CAREC ministerial conferences, senior officials’ 
meetings (SOM), meetings of sector coordinating committees, and other meetings under the 
OIF, including those in support of second-tier activities, in the period 2007–2009.17 These

meetings  will  play  a  vital  role  in  fostering  a  regional  perspective  on  cooperation  and 
development  shared  by  all  participating  countries  that  will  facilitate  (i)  the  formulation  and 
implementation  of  the  strategic  direction  of  the  Program;  (ii)  the  development  and 
implementation  of  regional  sector  strategies  for  transportation,  energy,  and  trade;  (iii)  the 
formulation of prioritized regional investment programs and design of regional projects; and (iv) 
the monitoring of program performance and results. The RETA will support closer coordination 
with  other  development  partners  and  regional  organizations  to  maximize  opportunities  for 
regional cooperation, and to avoid overlap and duplication of effort.18  
 
13.  In addition, the RETA will support the CAREC NFP in each participating country by 
funding national advisors to the NFP and local regional cooperation coordinators (RCCs). These 
people  will  facilitate  the  smooth  functioning  of  the  OIF  and  substantive  interaction  among 
delegations at CAREC meetings. The national advisors will assist the NFPs with in-country 
coordination among ministries and agencies involved in, or impacted by, CAREC Program 
decisions to ensure timely implementation of CAREC agreements, and, with the RCCs, facilitate 
communication with the secretariat. Among other tasks, the RCCs will support preparation of 
reports and organization of meetings and other events. Senior advisors will advise the CAREC 
Unit on program management. A special advisor will assist the secretariat in engaging CAREC 
countries in defining and implementing regional cooperation and integration initiatives, and 
networking with development partners in mobilizing resources for regional cooperation. 
 
2.  Analytical Work in Support of Planning and Establishment of the CAREC 
Institute 
14.  The CAREC Program has produced reports assessing regional cooperation options for 
CAREC countries. These analyses have added substance to a growing understanding of the 
potential benefits of cooperation and, importantly, the costs of noncooperation. The RETA will 
support further analytical work to facilitate well-informed, realistic decision making based on a 
clear understanding of the potential gains, drawbacks, and risks involved in various regional 
cooperation initiatives, and to strengthen the Program’s strategic direction. 
 
15.  The  RETA  will  also  support  establishment  of  a  CAREC  Institute  to  lead  Program 
activities under the knowledge and capacity-building function of the CAP. The institute will act 
as  a  center  of  excellence  for  the  region  and  (i)  introduce  international  best  practices,  (ii) 
undertake sector studies to determine possible areas of comparative advantage, and (iii) identify 
new  market  opportunities.  The  institute  will  have  three  broad  roles:  (i)  to  lead  capacity-
development efforts under CAREC;19 (ii) to develop a network of experts and researchers, and 
coordinate research and analysis relevant to regional cooperation in CAREC countries;20 and (iii) 
to foster policy dialogue among and beyond the CAREC countries on key regional cooperation 
issues with a range of parties, including government officials, business leaders, and civil society.

3.  Information  Dissemination  and  Constituency  Building  for  Regional 
Cooperation 
16.  The RETA will support seminars, workshops, and other outreach activities in CAREC 
countries and outside the CAREC region to (i) expand awareness of the of the Program, (ii) 
raise awareness of developments and opportunities in the CAREC region among development 
partners and civil society, (iii) highlight the benefits of cooperation for CAREC countries, and (iv) 
improve sharing of information and experience among countries and development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The RETA is estimated to cost $5.2 million. ADB will finance $4.5 million of this amount 
from  its  TA  funding  program  and  will  also  administer  $500,000,  to  be  provided  by  the 
Government of the People's Republic of China.21 The participating governments will provide the 
remaining $200,000, which is the estimated value of participating government logistical support 
for meetings and staff time for activities conducted under the RETA. Detailed cost estimates are 
provided in Appendix 2. Supplemental funding will be required to support a full program of 
activities for the CAREC Institute. Such funds will be sought from interested development 
partners  and  used  to  finance  activities  not  adequately  covered  by  ADB  financing  and  to 
selectively expand existing activities with a focus on training and research. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The RETA will be implemented over 31 months from 1 September 2007 to 31 March 
2010. ADB will be the executing agency. ADB's CAREC Unit in the Country Coordination and 
Regional Cooperation Division of the Central and West Asia Department will be responsible for 
overall implementation of RETA activities.  
 
19.  For  implementation  of  this  RETA,  approximately  22  person-months  of  international 
consulting services will be engaged annually on an intermittent basis to assist with analytical 
works and planning. Approximately 294 person-months of national consulting services will be 
required  annually    to  support  the  NFPs,  country  reporting  and  coordination,  knowledge 
dissemination, and technical support to the secretariat. The consultants will be engaged by ADB 
on an individual basis in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). An outline of the terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
Equipment budgeted under the RETA consists of a limited amount of computers and office 
equipment that will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time) and left with the CAREC Unit upon completion of the RETA. 
 
20.  The outputs of the RETA will be disseminated at CAREC ministerial conferences, which 
receive significant media coverage, and through the CAREC pages on the ADB website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of the People's Republic of China; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $4,500,000  on  a  grant  basis,  for  Strengthening  Central  Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation, 2007–2009.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Approximately  22  person-months  of  international  and  294  person-months  of  domestic 
consulting  services  will  be  required  annually  for  the  proposed  regional  technical  assistance 
(RETA).  Given  the  RETA  will  support  a  range  of  activities  under  the  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program, some of which are still being planned, detailed terms of 
reference for specific tasks may be revised and supplemented at a later stage as appropriate. 
B.  International Consultants 
1.  Special Advisor (2 person-months) 
2.  Independent individual consultant(s) will be engaged to provide the following services. 
(i)  Assist the CAREC secretariat in structuring ministerial conferences and interaction 
with development partners, and assist with program outreach activities. 
(ii)  Assist  the  CAREC  secretariat  in  ensuring  implementation  of  the  CAREC 
comprehensive action plan. 
(iii)  Provide  guidance  and  advice  to  the  leadership  of  the  CAREC  Institute  on  its 
developing role, research program, and functions; act as a resource person at 
CAREC Program and CAREC Institute activities as required. 
(iv)  Advise the CAREC secretariat in establishing productive working relationships with 
other regional cooperation organizations working in Central Asia and neighboring 
countries, as well as with bilateral and multilateral donors interested in CAREC. 
(v)  Review and comment on policy notes and other relevant documents and plans. 
 
2.  Senior Advisors (8 person-months) 
3.  Independent individual consultant(s) will be engaged to provide the following services. 
(i)  Perform analytical studies of regional cooperation in relation to further strengthening 
of the overall institutional framework (OIF) and the strategic direction of the CAREC 
Program. 
(ii)  Assist implementation and updating of the CAREC comprehensive action plan. 
(iii)  Perform other analytical studies as required, particularly in the priority areas of 
transport, energy, trade policy, and trade facilitation. 
(iv)  Advise on, and assist in, promoting participation of the private sector and business 
communities in the CAREC Program. 
(v)  Assist the head of the CAREC Unit in planning, preparing for, and implementing 
conferences and meetings for the CAREC Program, including the preparation of 
resource papers. 
(vi)  Provide other technical and coordinating support to the OIF of the CAREC Program, 
as required. 
 
3.  Sector Experts (12 person-months) 
4.  Independent individual consultant(s) will be engaged on an intermittent basis to undertake 
analysis and prepare reports as required to meet the requests of the CAREC senior officials'

Appendix 3  11 
meetings and ministerial conferences. An annual work program will be prepared following each 
ministerial conference (see main text paragraph 12). 
C.  National Consultants 
1.  National Advisor to CAREC National Focal Point (8 positions, total 96 person-
months) 
5.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged (one per CAREC participating country) 
to  provide  advisory  services  and  other  assistance  to  the  national  focal  point  (NFP)  in 
institutionalizing  regional  cooperation  and  in  planning  and  implementing  regional  cooperation 
activities. The consultants will be engaged to provide the following services.  
(i)  Assist  the  further  strengthening  of  communication  channels  for  the  NFP  with 
relevant sector focal points within the country and with the secretariat to ensure 
effective communication, and support CAREC-related information development and 
dissemination. 
(ii)  Assist the government with preparations for CAREC meetings and conferences, 
including preparation of supporting materials such as position papers and speeches. 
(iii)  Provide support for the effective implementation of ongoing assistance projects in 
CAREC priority areas as required. 
(iv)  Cooperate  closely  with  the  regional  cooperation  coordinator  in  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  resident  mission  concerned  to  ensure  effective 
implementation of CAREC activities. 
(v)  Assist in the implementation and monitoring of the CAREC comprehensive action 
plan. 
(vi)  Assist in the preparation of studies and other research conducted in the country 
under  the  CAREC  umbrella  as  appropriate,  and  to  include  a  quarterly  report 
summarizing regional activities within the country of assignment. 
(vii)  Perform other regional cooperation and ADB-related tasks as assigned by the head 
of the CAREC Unit. 
 
2.  Regional Cooperation Coordinator (8 positions, total 96 person-months) 
6.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged (one per CAREC participating country) 
to provide the following services. 
(i)  Serve as a focal point for regional economic cooperation in the CAREC participating 
country, coordinating CAREC-related issues with national and sector focal points in 
the government, other government bodies involved in regional cooperation activities, 
representatives  of  multilateral  institutions  and  other  aid  agencies  in  the  field, 
business communities, and other stakeholders.  
(ii)  Through regular contact and consultation, establish long-term working relationships 
with government agencies responsible for regional economic cooperation. 
(iii)  Undertake  or  provide  inputs  into  CAREC-related  economic  research,  studies 
(sector, strategy, or thematic), and other analytical work, including assistance in 
monitoring implementation of the CAREC comprehensive action plan. 
(iv)  Assist in the logistics and other arrangements for meetings and conferences under 
the OIF, including ad-hoc working group meetings, sector coordinating committee 
meetings,  senior  officials'  meetings,  and  ministerial  conferences,  as  well  as  in-
country workshops and outreach seminars.

12  Appendix 3 
(v)  Monitor programs and initiatives of the government, regional organizations, and 
other  stakeholders  on  regional  economic  cooperation;  identify,  evaluate,  and 
recommend potential areas for collaboration. 
(vi)  Perform  other  regional  cooperation  and  ADB-related  tasks  as  assigned  by  the 
country director or head of the CAREC Unit. 
3.  CAREC Institute Advisor (12 person-months) 
7.  A senior economist with extensive experience and considerable regional standing will be 
engaged to undertake the following primary responsibilities. 
(i)  Provide overall direction and day-to-day management of the research, capacity 
development, and dialogue activities of the CAREC Institute. 
(ii)  Manage the budget of the CAREC Institute. 
(iii)  Develop and execute a plan to raise awareness of the CAREC Institute among the 
academic and business communities within CAREC countries and beyond, and 
develop networks of researchers.  
(iv)  Assist with fundraising activities.  
(v)  Carry out other activities as may be assigned by the head of the CAREC Unit. 
 
4.  CAREC Institute Coordinator (12 person-months)  
8.  An economist with broad experience in CAREC countries will be engaged to assist the 
CAREC Institute advisor in all aspects of the development and functioning of the CAREC Institute. 
(Terms of reference will be further developed in coordination with the CAREC Institute advisor 
based on the endorsed work program and budget for the institute.) 
5.  CAREC Institute Administrative Assistant (12 person-months) 
9.  An administrative assistant will be engaged to provide support to the operations of the 
CAREC Institute. (Terms of reference will be further developed in coordination with the CAREC 
Institute Advisor based on the endorsed work program and budget for the Institute.) 
6.  Sector Experts (18 person-months) 
10.  Independent individual consultant(s) will be engaged on an intermittent basis to undertake 
analysis and prepare reports as required to meet the requests of the CAREC senior officials' 
meetings and ministerial conferences. An annual work program will be prepared following each 
ministerial conference (see main text paragraph 12). 
7.  Development Economist (12 person-months) 
11.  A development economist based at ADB headquarters will be engaged to undertake the 
following primary responsibilities: 
(i)  Provide technical and logistical assistance to the CAREC Unit. 
(ii)  Oversee logistics and related arrangements for CAREC ministerial conferences and 
senior officials’ meetings, prepare resource papers for these meetings, and perform 
follow-up activities. 
(iii)  Assist  in  arrangements  for  sector  coordinating  committee  meetings,  outreach 
seminars, and other CAREC workshops and meetings.

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  Prepare  periodic  monitoring  reports  on  CAREC  Program  implementation,  which 
covers  the  status  of  proposed  program  activities  and  other  related  initiatives, 
financial status of CAREC RETAs, and other outstanding operational issues. 
(v)  Create, maintain, and upgrade a database for the analysis and measurement of 
results and outcomes of the CAREC Program. 
(vi)  Help  prepare  CAREC-related  documents  such  as  concept  papers  and  project 
profiles for regional projects, briefing notes, and other background papers.  
(vii)  Undertake other activities as may be assigned by head of the CAREC Unit. 
8.  Website and Publications Expert (12 person-months) 
12.  A website and publications expert will be engaged to undertake the following primary 
responsibilities. 
(i)  Assist in developing the concept and redesign of the CAREC section of the ADB 
website. 
(ii)  Develop and ensure regular update of the website. 
(iii)  Provide inputs to the preparation of other information materials and reports. 
(iv)  Supervise the layout, typesetting, and translation of CAREC publications.  
(v)  Liaise with the ADB Department of External Relations and the Printing Unit for the 
clearance and production of CAREC publications.  
(vi)  Assist in the preparation of presentation materials, reports, and other documents for 
use in high-level meetings and conferences.  
(vii)  Undertake other activities assigned by the head of the CAREC Unit. 
 
9.  Regional Cooperation Programs Analyst (12 person-months) 
13.  A  regional  cooperation  programs  analyst  will  provide  statistical,  analytical,  and 
administrative support to the implementation of the CAREC Program. The consultant will be based 
in Manila and have the following specific responsibilities: 
(i)  Assist in updating information on the regional lending and technical assistance plans 
of CAREC multilateral institution partners. 
(ii)  Provide logistical support in organizing and conducting CAREC sector committee 
meetings, senior officials’ meetings, and ministerial conferences as well as outreach 
seminars and other workshops. 
(iii)  Collect statistical data and maintain a database in support of the requirements of 
CAREC reports and publications. 
(iv)  Maintain an orderly and up-to-date resource library (including electronic copies) of 
RETA  files,  CAREC  documents,  consultants’  reports,  and  other  research  and 
background papers on regional cooperation. 
(v)  Assist in processing requests for consultant engagement and contract variations; 
provide general administrative support to the CAREC Unit. 
(vi)  Ensure the smooth flow of documents and communications between the CAREC 
Unit and various divisions of the Central and West Asia Department, the East Asia 
Department, and the resident missions. 
(vii)  Perform other related tasks as may be assigned by the head of the CAREC Unit. 
10.  Administrative Assistant (12 person-months) 
14.  An administrative assistant will be engaged to provide administrative support to all aspects 
of the work of the CAREC Unit.
